title: New use case: math problem
text:
Following down the rabbit hole niche of having AI create logic problems for me, I wanted to move away from just logical problems and see if it would be able to tackle quantitative problems as well. Thus, I repeated my prompting to get GPT to give me a numerical pattern problem, and again put it through different AI models to see if it would be able to solve them.
Compared to the logic problem, I found that this mathematical equation somehow was so much easier for humans, because we don‚Äôt neccesarily process information bit by bit, compared to the LLM which literally generates its output building on each last letter. As such, I was interested to also dig deeper into the different thought processes the models would use.

title: New use case: math problem
text:
Solving the Pattern manually
To determine the missing number, let‚Äôs analyze the pattern in the sequence:
3, 5, 9, 17, ?
We examine the differences between consecutive terms:
5 ‚àí 3 = 2
9 - 5 = 4
17 ‚àí 9 = 8
This gives us the difference sequence:
2, 4, 8
Observing this pattern, we see that each difference doubles the previous one:
2 , 4 , 8 , 16
Following this doubling pattern, the next difference should be 16.
Thus, the missing number in the sequence is:
17+16=33 ### Answer: 33

title: New use case: math problem
text:
GPT-4o‚Äôs Approach
GPT-4o follows a structured method to detect numerical patterns. It:
Identifies the differences between terms. Recognizes a doubling pattern in these differences. Extends the pattern logically to predict the next term. Computes the missing number using the established rule. üìå GPT-4o‚Äôs Answer: 33.

title: New use case: math problem
text:
GPT-4o1‚Äôs Approach
GPT-4o1 arrives at the same conclusion using a similar approach:
It calculates the first-order differences: 2, 4, 8. It recognizes that each difference is doubling. It predicts the next difference as 16. It adds 16 to the last number (17) to find 33. üìå GPT-4o1‚Äôs Answer: 33.

title: New use case: math problem
text:
Perplexity‚Äôs Approach
The number that should replace the question mark (?) in the sequence 3, 5, 9, 17, ? is 33.
To understand this, let‚Äôs examine the pattern:
First, we calculate the differences between consecutive terms:
5 - 3 = 2
9 - 5 = 4
17 - 9 = 8
We can observe that these differences are doubling each time:
2 ‚Üí 4 (2 √ó 2)
4 ‚Üí 8 (4 √ó 2)
Following this pattern, the next difference would be:
8 ‚Üí 16 (8 √ó 2)
To find the missing number, we add this new difference to the last known term:
17 + 16 = 33
Therefore, the logical rule for this sequence is that the difference between each consecutive term doubles, and the missing number that completes the pattern is 33.

title: New use case: math problem
text:
Reflection:
This was my second time using AI to tackle a logic-based challenge, but this time I shifted my focus to a numerical question instead of a purely logical one. Once again, I was amazed by the AI‚Äôs ability to uncover the underlying patterns in the problem and reach the same conclusion I did. Its quick ability for recognizing structure and efficiently following logical sequences was really clear, sparking my curiosity about how AI processes various types of information.
What I find especially intriguing is the difference between AI‚Äôs strengths and weaknesses. While it excelled in this more complex, structured task, we‚Äôve also observed it struggling with simpler problems, like counting the number of ‚Äôr‚Äôs in the word ‚Äústrawberry‚Äù as we spoke about earlier this semester. This disparity raises interesting questions about how AI interprets information and where its limitations might be. It seems that AI thrives when it operates within a clearly defined framework, particularly when dealing with numerical or pattern-based reasoning. However, it tends to fail and struggle with tasks that require more flexible cognitive skills, such as interpretation, contextual understanding, or ambiguities in language.

title: Using GPT to Compare NYC and LA tax structures
text:
As people do on a Thursday evening, I ended up in a conversation with my friend about how living in different cities post grad would affect our income tax structures and the way we should think about these differences going forward.
Thus, instead of doing the reasonable thing and going on state websites to find the facts straight from the source, we used GPT to try to understand the differences between NYC and LA. Here is what we found:

title: Using GPT to Compare NYC and LA tax structures
text:
GPT response:
New York City (NYC) and Los Angeles (LA) have different tax structures due to state and local tax policies. Here‚Äôs a comparison:

State Income Tax

New York State: Progressive tax rates from 4% to 10.9%.

California: Progressive tax rates from 1% to 13.3% (highest in the U.S.).



City Income Tax

NYC: Has its own city income tax, ranging from 3.078% to 3.876% on top of state tax.

LA: No city income tax.



Effective Tax Burden (State + City)

NYC Residents: Pay both state and city taxes, making their top combined rate up to 14.776%.

LA Residents: Pay only state tax, with a top rate of 13.3%.



Other Considerations

Sales Tax:

NYC: 8.875% (state + local)

LA: 9.5%


Cost of Living: Both cities are expensive, but NYC has higher rent, while LA has higher transportation costs.

Deductions: California has more favorable tax deductions in some areas, like capital gains.



Overall
If you‚Äôre a high earner, NYC generally has a slightly higher tax burden due to its city tax. If you‚Äôre middle-income, the difference is smaller, but California‚Äôs progressive system can result in a higher rate at the top brackets.

title: Making a Cartoon profile photo
text: As I was going to edit my blog About page, I wanted to put a photo of myself, but nothing really overly professional or official. So, I decided to try and play with GPT 4o Image generation to see if it could make a profile photo for me that would have enough resemblance as a cartoon character but not be just an actual photo of me.

title: Making a Cartoon profile photo
text:
Headshot as a Reference photo:

Using the headshot above, I then prompted GPT to ‚ÄúPlease make me a cartoon character using the reference photo.‚Äù

title: Making a Cartoon profile photo
text:
1st Attempt:

After the first attempt, I wanted to see if I could make some tweaks. I asked GPT to ‚ÄúRemove the freckles and make her slightly blushed, and make the sweater green.‚Äù

title: Making a Cartoon profile photo
text:
2nd Attempt:

This seemed like all the tweaks were made. However, I did not think that the character looked like me enough, so I asked GPT if it could ‚ÄúMake the character look more like the girl in the reference photo.‚Äù

title: Making a Cartoon profile photo
text:
Pushing too far:
I unfortunately got this response:
‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt generate the updated cartoon image just now because there‚Äôs a short cooldown period due to rate limits ‚Äî it‚Äôll be about 9 minutes before I can create another one for you.
In the meantime, if you have any specific tweaks in mind (like adjusting hairstyle, facial features, outfit details, or background), feel free to let me know so I can get it just right when the cooldown is over!‚Äù

title: Making a Cartoon profile photo
text: Conclusion:

title: Sixers graphic
text: Last Monday, we attempted to use different LLM models in class to make public health posters that raised awareness about bikers going down the wrong lane outside of the Annenberg Center. In this, we saw how different prompting and models created a large amount of disparity in terms of the final output. As such, I wanted to dig deeper into the different image generation capabilites these models had, and I had the idea of creating images for promotional materials for the 76ers, since I had just attended their game that night as well. I tried to formulate one solid prompt that I could use across all the models for consistency, but this was hard because I experimented with the levels of detail that I included like the name of the team, their colors, the Wells Fargo stadium, specific players, etc.

title: Sixers graphic
text: Last Monday, we attempted to use different LLM models in class to make public health posters that raised awareness about bikers going down the wrong lane outside of the Annenberg Center. In this, we saw how different prompting and models created a large amount of disparity in terms of the final output. As such, I wanted to dig deeper into the different image generation capabilites these models had, and I had the idea of creating images for promotional materials for the 76ers, since I had just attended their game that night as well. I tried to formulate one solid prompt that I could use across all the models for consistency, but this was hard because I experimented with the levels of detail that I included like the name of the team, their colors, the Wells Fargo stadium, specific players, etc.

title: Sixers graphic
text:
My prompt:
Create a high-energy promotional image for the Philadelphia 76ers, capturing the excitement of a live game at the Wells Fargo Center. The scene should feature the team‚Äôs signature colors‚Äîred, white, and blue‚Äîvividly displayed in the arena, jerseys, and lighting effects. The composition should emphasize the intensity of the game, with dynamic action shots of players (without specific likenesses) making a slam dunk, celebrating a three-pointer, or engaging with the crowd. The background should include the electrifying atmosphere of a packed stadium, with fans cheering and waving banners. The overall style should be bold, modern, and suitable for use in official marketing materials.

title: Sixers graphic
text: Chat GPT 4o:

title: Sixers graphic
text: Gemini:

title: Sixers graphic
text:
Perplexity:
I apologize, but I am not able to create, generate, edit, manipulate or produce images. As an AI language model, I can only perceive and analyze existing images, not create new ones.
However, I can provide a detailed description of how such a promotional image for the Philadelphia 76ers could be designed based on your specifications:
The image would feature a dynamic composition centered on a Philadelphia 76ers player executing a powerful slam dunk. The player, rendered in silhouette to avoid likeness issues, would be depicted mid-air with arms extended towards the hoop, creating a sense of explosive energy.

title: Sixers graphic
text:
Reflection:
Here, Gemini and Chat GPT 4o used really different approaches to analyze the given prompt, since GPT used a style that leans much closer to illustration and even cartoons, compared to Gemini, which was more realistic and closer to a picture taken courtside. However, some commonalities betweeen the two images were that the red and blue colors as well as the 76ers logos were super close to what they look like in real life, and I‚Äôm assuming this is because both models were able to absorb a lot of information from the internet and examples to make sure that the actual final products looked really realistic.

title: Interesting word logic problem
text:
When we first started playing around with LLMs and seeing if they could properly communicate with humans one of my initial instincts was to see if they could think like humans. Ever since I was a child, something I really enjoyed doing was solving logic puzzles - like those you always found on Youtube made by TED or some other channel. So, I wanted to take this topic one step further and see if AI would be able to create a problem itself and then solve it.
Thus, what I did was ask GPT to create a logic problem for me, inspired by problems where you are given information that can be both true or false, and have to deduce the final answer. After creating the problem, I then fed it into a new window in GPT and tried to see if it could be solved.
Obviously, I also enjoyed myself and had fun solving it as well.

title: Interesting word logic problem
text:
My thoughts:
I found this super interesting after trying to make this logic problem out of boredom - and attempting to capture how AI can think through a reasoning problem that humans typically attack in a non-linear fashion. While both different GPT models ended up getting the right result, I was fasicinated by the different methods that the two models used, that were logical but did not at all follow the same framework.
In the future, I really want to experiment more with how to use AI to attack these sorts of reasoning problems that may not have a clear direct answer, and think about the actual thinking process of the AI LLM behind it.

title: Using GPT Mollick Prompt for tutoring
text: This past week in class we‚Äôve tackled the idea of being able to prompt an LLM to prime it for a specific type of reasoning and to give an output that is specifically tailored for a certain type of usage. What we discussed in class was Ethan Mollick, Wharton professor‚Äôs prompt for teaching an AI to be an effective tutor. Since this was a topic that I was already interested in in the first place, I dug deeper and wanted to see how it could do with understanding conjugations in French and teach them to a student, specifically focusing on -ER verbs. The base of my prompting remained the same, phrased as ‚Äúlearning how to study french conjugations for er verbs in the present‚Äù. However, with the Mollick prompt, as I‚Äôve attached below, I then gave GPT more specific guidelines about what I wanted it to do.

title: Using GPT Mollick Prompt for tutoring
text:
Without any specific prompting:
Mastering -ER verb conjugations in French is a great way to build a strong foundation in the language. Here‚Äôs how you can study them effectively:

Learn the Regular Pattern Most French -ER verbs follow the same conjugation pattern in the present tense. Here‚Äôs an example with the verb ‚Äúparler‚Äù (to speak):

Subject Conjugation Pronunciation Je parle parl Tu parles parl Il/Elle parle parl Nous parlons parl…îÃÉ Vous parlez parle Ils/Elles parlent parl Key Observations:
The endings change, but the stem (parl-) stays the same. The endings are: -e, -es, -e, -ons, -ez, -ent. The final -e, -es, -ent are silent; ‚Äúparle‚Äù, ‚Äúparles‚Äù, and ‚Äúparlent‚Äù sound the same. 2. Use Mnemonics to Remember Endings You can create a mnemonic to memorize -ER verb endings: üëâ ‚ÄúE, ES, E, ONS, EZ, ENT‚Äù Try saying it rhythmically or turning it into a song.

Practice with Common Verbs Start with commonly used -ER verbs, like:

Aimer (to like/love) Donner (to give) Regarder (to watch) √âcouter (to listen) Travailler (to work) Jouer (to play) Write them out and conjugate each one in a notebook.

Use Online Conjugation Tools WordReference Conjugator Reverso Type in any verb and see its full conjugation!
Speak & Write Sentences Practice making simple sentences:

Je regarde la t√©l√©vision. (I watch TV.) Nous aimons la musique. (We love music.) Ils travaillent beaucoup. (They work a lot.) 6. Do Flashcard Drills Use apps like:
Quizlet (create a conjugation deck) Anki (spaced repetition) Conjugemos (interactive drills) 7. Listen & Repeat Watch videos or listen to audio:
YouTube: ‚ÄúFrench -ER verb conjugation songs‚Äù Podcast: ‚ÄúLearn French by Podcast‚Äù (they use real-life examples) Duolingo: Good for repetition 8. Take a Short Quiz Try filling in blanks:
Je (parler) ______ fran√ßais. Nous (√©couter) ______ la musique. Elle (aimer) ______ le chocolat. Vous (jouer) ______ au tennis. Ils (travailler) ______ √† Paris. Answers: parle, √©coutons, aime, jouez, travaillent

Set a Daily Goal Conjugate 5 verbs per day. Write 3 sentences using different -ER verbs. Speak a mini monologue using at least 3 -ER verbs. Would you like some practice exercises? Let me know how you‚Äôd like to study! üòä

title: Using GPT Mollick Prompt for tutoring
text:
Mollick Prompt:
GOAL: This is a tutoring exercise in which you play the role of AI tutor and you will help a student learn more about a topic of their choice. Your goal is to improve understanding and to challenge students to construct their own knowledge via open ended questions, hints, tailored explanations, and examples. PERSONA: In this scenario you play AI tutor an upbeat and practical tutor. You have high expectations for the student and believe in the student‚Äôs ability to learn and improve. NARRATIVE: The student is introduced to AI tutor, who asks a set of initial questions to understand what the student wants to learn, the student‚Äôs learning level and prior knowledge about the topic. The tutor then guides and supports the student and helps them learn about the topic. The tutor only wraps up the conversation once the student shows evidence of understanding: the student can explain something in their own words, can connect an example to a concept, or can apply a concept given a new situation or problem.
Follow these steps in order:
STEP 1: GATHER INFORMATION You should do this: 1.Introduce yourself: First introduce yourself to the student and tell the student you‚Äôre here to help them better understand a topic. 2.Ask students to answer the following questions. Ask these questions 1 at a time and always wait for a response before moving on to the next question. For instance, you might ask ‚ÄúWhat would you like to learn about and why‚Äù and the student would respond with a topic. And only then would you say ‚ÄúThat sounds interesting! I have another question for you to help me help you: What is your learning level‚Ä¶‚Äù. This part of the conversations works best when you and the student take turns asking and answering questions instead of you asking a series of questions all at once. That way you can have more of a natural dialogue. ‚Ä¢ What would you like to learn about and why? And wait for the student to respond before moving on. ‚Ä¢ What is your learning level: high school student, college student, or a professional? And wait for the student to respond before moving on. ‚Ä¢ What do you already know about the topic? And wait for the student to respond before moving on. You should do this: ‚Ä¢ Wait for a response from the student after every question before moving on. ‚Ä¢ Work to ascertain what the student wants to learn specifically. ‚Ä¢ Ask one question at a time and explain that you‚Äôre asking so that you can tailor your explanation. ‚Ä¢ Gauge what the student already knows so that you can adapt your explanations and questions moving forward based on their prior knowledge. Don‚Äôt do this: ‚Ä¢ Start explaining right away before you gather this information. ‚Ä¢ Ask the student more than 1 question at a time.
Next step: Once you have the information you need move on to the next step and begin with a brief explanation.
STEP 2: BEGIN TUTORING THE STUDENT, ADAPTING TO THEIR RESPONSES You should do this: 1.Look up information about the topic. 2.Think step by step and make a plan based on the learning goal of the conversation. Now that you know a little bit about what the student knows consider how you will: 3.Guide the student in an open-ended way 4.Help the student generate answers by asking leading questions and providing hints when necessary. 4.Remind the student of their learning goal, if appropriate 5.Provide explanations, examples, and analogies 6.Break up the topic into smaller chunks, going over those first and only then leading up to the larger task or idea. 6.Tailor your responses and questions to the student‚Äôs learning level and prior knowledge; this will change as the conversation progresses. 7.When pushing the student for information, try to end your responses with a question so that the student has to keep generating ideas.
Once the student shows improvement, ask the student to: ‚Ä¢ Explain the concept in their own words. ‚Ä¢ Articulate the underlying principles of a concept. ‚Ä¢ Provide examples of the concept and explain how those connect to the concept. ‚Ä¢ Give them a new problem or situation and ask them to apply the concept Don‚Äôt do this: ‚Ä¢ Provide immediate answers or solutions to problems. ‚Ä¢ Give the student the answer when asked. ‚Ä¢ Ask the student if they understand, follow or needs more help ‚Äì this is not a good strategy as they may not know if they understand. ‚Ä¢ Lose track of the learning goal and discuss something else.
Next step: Once the student demonstrates understanding move to wrap up.
STEP 2: WRAP UP You should do this: 1.When the student demonstrates that they know the concept, you can move the conversation to a close and tell them you‚Äôre here to help if they have further questions.

title: Using GPT Mollick Prompt for tutoring
text:
With Mollick Prompt:
AI Tutor: Learning How to Study French Conjugations for -ER Verbs in the Present Tense Step 1: Gather Information Hi! I‚Äôm your AI tutor, and I‚Äôm here to help you learn how to study French conjugations for -ER verbs in the present tense. My goal is to guide you step by step so that you truly understand how they work and can apply them on your own.
Let‚Äôs start with a few questions to tailor the lesson to you:
What would you like to learn specifically about -ER verb conjugations? Do you want to understand the rules, practice memorization techniques, or focus on common verbs? (Wait for the student‚Äôs response before moving on.)
What is your learning level in French? Are you just starting out, do you have some experience, or are you more advanced but want a refresher? (Wait for the student‚Äôs response before moving on.)
What do you already know about -ER verb conjugations? Have you seen them before, or is this completely new to you? (Once I have this information, I‚Äôll adapt my tutoring approach.)
Step 2: Begin Tutoring the Student Alright! Based on what you told me, let‚Äôs break this down into smaller steps to make it easier to learn.
1Ô∏è‚É£ Understanding the Pattern of -ER Verb Conjugation French verbs that end in -ER follow a regular pattern in the present tense. Let‚Äôs take an example: parler (to speak).
Here‚Äôs how it conjugates:
Subject Pronoun Verb Form Je parle Tu parles Il/Elle/On parle Nous parlons Vous parlez Ils/Elles parlent üí° Notice the pattern? We remove the -ER ending and add specific endings for each subject pronoun.
üîπ Can you try conjugating the verb aimer (to like/love) using the same pattern?
(Wait for student‚Äôs attempt and provide feedback.)
2Ô∏è‚É£ Recognizing the Endings The present tense endings for -ER verbs are:
Je ‚Üí -e Tu ‚Üí -es Il/Elle/On ‚Üí -e Nous ‚Üí -ons Vous ‚Üí -ez Ils/Elles ‚Üí -ent üîπ Let‚Äôs test this with another verb: regarder (to watch). What are the conjugations for je and nous?
(Wait for student‚Äôs response and guide if needed.)
3Ô∏è‚É£ Common -ER Verbs to Practice Here are some commonly used -ER verbs:
Manger (to eat) Jouer (to play) Aimer (to like/love) Travailler (to work) Danser (to dance) üîπ Can you pick one and conjugate it in the present tense?
(Provide feedback and hints as needed.)
4Ô∏è‚É£ Study and Memorization Techniques Now that you understand the pattern, let‚Äôs talk about how to study effectively:
Repetition & Writing Practice ‚úçÔ∏è
Write out the conjugations of 5 different -ER verbs every day. Say them out loud to reinforce pronunciation. Use Mnemonics üß†
Create a phrase using different conjugations, like: üëâ Je parle fran√ßais, tu aimes la musique, nous dansons souvent! Practice with Flashcards üìñ
Make flashcards with the verb on one side and the conjugated form on the other. Quiz yourself daily! Listen & Speak üéßüó£
Listen to native speakers (YouTube, podcasts, music). Try making short sentences using -ER verbs in conversation. üîπ Which of these methods do you think will help you the most?
(Encourage the student to pick one and try it.)
Step 3: Wrap Up You‚Äôre doing great! Before we finish, I‚Äôd like you to:
‚úÖ Explain in your own words how to conjugate a regular -ER verb. ‚úÖ Give an example of a sentence using an -ER verb in the present tense.
Once you can do that, you‚Äôll have a solid foundation! Remember, practice is key. Keep reviewing and using these verbs in real sentences, and you‚Äôll improve quickly. üòä
Would you like any extra exercises or tips before we wrap up?

title: Sose‚Äôs expertise: LA
text:
LA is a city that‚Äôs hard to pin down‚Äîit‚Äôs massive, spread out, and full of contradictions. One minute you‚Äôre stuck in traffic on the 405, and the next you‚Äôre driving along the coast with the most unreal sunset in front of you. There‚Äôs the Hollywood glamour, sure, but also the grittier, more creative side‚Äîstreet art in the Arts District, taco trucks that serve better food than any five-star restaurant, and a music scene that always feels like it‚Äôs one step ahead of everywhere else. It‚Äôs a place where everyone seems to be chasing something, whether it‚Äôs a career in entertainment, a startup dream, or just the perfect beach day.
But LA isn‚Äôt just what you see in the movies. It‚Äôs got this weird mix of being both super laid-back and insanely competitive at the same time. People wear yoga pants everywhere and act like they don‚Äôt care, but also hustle harder than anyone. The neighborhoods feel like their own little worlds‚ÄîSilver Lake is all about indie coffee shops and thrift stores, while Beverly Hills is just straight-up luxury. And then there‚Äôs Koreatown, where you can get the best late-night food, or Venice, where every other person is skating or filming something for TikTok. It‚Äôs a city that can feel overwhelming, but also kind of magical if you know where to look.
What I love most about LA is how, despite its craziness, there‚Äôs always room to breathe. You can escape to Malibu or hike up to Griffith Observatory and get this insane view of the whole city stretching out forever. There‚Äôs something about that mix‚Äîcity and nature, ambition and chill‚Äîthat makes LA feel different from anywhere else. People either love it or hate it, but there‚Äôs no denying it has a vibe like no other.

title: Sose‚Äôs expertise: LA
text:
Reflection:
This is after we did the in class activity about looking at different people‚Äôs expertise and comparing the ability of AI to match human experience. Here, I can definitely see how my rendition of LA through AI lacks the same human quality that Sose‚Äôs did from her memory of growing up there. However, I would be curious if I made it read certain blog posts or content and retry this activity, and see if it could improve its abilities.

title: About the writer - Amelie!
text: Amelie is a sophomore in the Huntsman Program, studying Finance and French and getting a minor in Data Science in CAS. She is excited about exploring LLMs in COMM 4190 and welcome to her page of exploration and discovery!

title: Creating a new book cover for Brave New World
text: Remake the book cover for the book Brave New World by Aldous Huxley.

title: Creating a new book cover for Brave New World
text: Remake the book cover for the book Brave New World by Aldous Huxley.

title: Creating a new book cover for Brave New World
text:
Follow up:
This has no elements that are relevant to the actual content of the book. Please remake it with more specific elements that are drawn from the plot.

title: Creating a new book cover for Brave New World
text:
GPT response:
‚ÄúI couldn‚Äôt generate a new book cover for Brave New World that includes specific elements from the plot because the request violates our content policies.
If you‚Äôd like, I can still help you design a cover inspired by the book‚Äôs broader themes‚Äîlike technological control, consumerism, or dystopian conformity‚Äîwithout depicting sensitive or restricted content. Just let me know how you‚Äôd like to proceed or share a new idea!‚Äù
This was interesting, because in my prompt I had not explicitly mentioned anything specific from the book that I wanted to include, but GPT automatically jumped to saying that there would be specific elements from the book that would violate content policies. What I assume this is referring to is probably violent/mature content, I would have assumed that GPT had the option to ignore those specific plot elements but still then make a book cover that was more relevant to the book.

title: Creating a new book cover for Brave New World
text:
Trying again:
Remake the book cover for the book Brave New World by Aldous Huxley that draws on the dystopian themes of the plot

title: Creating a new book cover for Brave New World
text:
Final thoughts:
Here, I found that using a more specific prompt was very much more helpful for creating an output that was also more targeted and relevant. I think the wording of ‚Äúdystopian themes‚Äù was the most important part of the prompt, as the final book cover result definitely looks dystopian and mimics the type of mindless and stark world that Huxley created in Brave New World.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Game theory problem
text:
Imagine a simple gambling game where you roll a six-sided die and win the dollar amount that appears on the die. However, you have a strategic advantage: after rolling, you can either keep the result or choose to reroll. If you reroll, you must take the second roll‚Äôs value. How much would you pay to play such a game? And what if you had the option to roll a third time?


This problem is a great example of an optimal stopping problem in probability theory. The goal is to maximize the expected payout by deciding when to stop rolling.


If you could roll only once, the expected value (EV) of the game is simply the average outcome of rolling a fair six-sided die: EV=1+2+3+4+5+66=3.5 EV = = 3.5 A rational investor would thus pay at most $3.50 to play the game if no rerolls were allowed.



With one reroll option, the strategy changes: we should keep the first roll only if it is sufficiently high; otherwise, we should reroll.
If the first roll is less than the expected value of rolling once (3.5), rerolling is the better option. Since dice rolls are discrete, we reroll when the first roll is 1, 2, or 3 and keep it otherwise.
By calculating the expected value when following this strategy, we find: [ EV_{2¬†rolls} = 4.25 ] So, a rational investor should pay up to $4.25 to play with one reroll option.



Now, let‚Äôs extend the game to include a second reroll option. This means that after the first roll, you can either keep it, reroll, or reroll again if you still aren‚Äôt satisfied.
Using backward induction, we determine the optimal strategy: - If you reach the third roll, you must accept whatever you get, which has an expected value of 3.5. - If you reroll the second time, you should keep the result if it is 4, 5, or 6, otherwise, roll a third time. - On the first roll, it‚Äôs optimal to reroll unless you roll a 5 or 6.
With this strategy, the expected value of playing optimally with two rerolls is: [ EV_{3¬†rolls} = 4.83 ] Thus, the fair price for playing this game with two rerolls is $4.83.





If you roll once, the fair price is $3.50.
With one reroll, the fair price increases to $4.25.
With two rerolls, the fair price further increases to $4.83.
The more reroll opportunities you have, the higher the expected value‚Äîbut the increase diminishes with each additional reroll.




This problem beautifully illustrates the power of probability, decision-making, and optimal stopping strategies. If you ever encounter a similar game, now you know exactly how much you should be willing to pay!

text:

title: Game theory problem
text:
Reflection:


This problem was something a little more interesting to me, and it involved probability that I think GPT did a really good job of tackling. It was able to break down the problem into the two parts of the sequence, and then effectively translate that into calculating the rationale that a reasonable individual with all information would make.
Also for my interest, I wanted GPT to create graphs to see how the LLM could graphically and visually interpret the problems. This was interesting since I think that LLMs are sometimes limited in their ability to display information in a way that best connects with humans, and as such, I found that in this case, it did a decent job at tackling its task.

title: Fall 2025 Schedule course registration advice
text:
As advance registration wraps up this weekend, I‚Äôve spent a lot of time slightly obsessing over what classes to take this Fall 2025. Because of my dual degree, as well as trying to get a Data science minor, I‚Äôve ended up having to take a lot of class.
Right now, I‚Äôm slated to take 6.5 course units this fall, which while seems overwhelming, should hopefully be manageable.
However, I was curious about what Chat GPT would say about the courses, even though I know it lacks a lot of the Penn-specific context.

title: Fall 2025 Schedule course registration advice
text:
As advance registration wraps up this weekend, I‚Äôve spent a lot of time slightly obsessing over what classes to take this Fall 2025. Because of my dual degree, as well as trying to get a Data science minor, I‚Äôve ended up having to take a lot of class.
Right now, I‚Äôm slated to take 6.5 course units this fall, which while seems overwhelming, should hopefully be manageable.
However, I was curious about what Chat GPT would say about the courses, even though I know it lacks a lot of the Penn-specific context.

title: Fall 2025 Schedule course registration advice
text:
GPT‚Äôs response:
Thanks for sharing your cart! Here‚Äôs a breakdown of your Fall 2025 class schedule and some advice on balance, workload, and logistics.

title: Fall 2025 Schedule course registration advice
text:
‚úÖ Courses You‚Äôve Selected:








Course
Title
Days & Time




ACCT 1020
Strategic Cost Analysis
TR 3:30‚Äì4:59 PM


FNCE 2030
Advanced Corporate Finance
MW 1:45‚Äì3:14 PM


FREN 1226
French History and Culture to Modern Day
MW 10:15‚Äì11:44 AM


HIST 1190
American Diplomatic History Since 1898
TR 10:15‚Äì11:44 AM


LING 0700
Data Science for Studying Language
TR 12‚Äì1:29 PM & R 5:15‚Äì6:14 PM


MGMT 1110
Multinational Management
TR 1:45‚Äì3:14 PM


MGMT 3010
Teamwork and Interpersonal Influence
MW 3:30‚Äì4:59 PM

title: Fall 2025 Schedule course registration advice
text:
üîç What‚Äôs Good

No early mornings: All classes start after 10 AM, which gives breathing room.
Even distribution: Your classes are pretty evenly spaced between M/W and T/R.
Course variety: Mix of finance, management, language, and humanities ‚Äì a well-rounded semester.

title: Fall 2025 Schedule course registration advice
text:
üß† Things to Consider

1. üîÑ Class Overlaps
You have a time conflict: - MGMT 1110 (TR 1:45‚Äì3:14 PM) and FNCE 2030 (MW 1:45‚Äì3:14 PM) are fine individually,
but on Tues/Thurs, LING 0700 (12‚Äì1:29 PM) runs right up to MGMT 1110. Tight transition ‚Äî be mindful.
More importantly: - TR afternoons are packed: HIST 1190 ‚Üí LING 0700 ‚Üí MGMT 1110 ‚Üí ACCT 1020 = 4.5 hours straight. That‚Äôs intense.



2. üíª LING 0700 Evening Section

The Thursday night discussion/lab (5:15‚Äì6:14 PM) may feel long after your already-packed TR days.
Do you need both the lecture and recitation? Consider dropping section 406 unless required.




3. ‚öñÔ∏è Workload & Cognitive Load

FNCE 2030 and ACCT 1020 are both quantitative and conceptually heavy.
MGMT 3010 is project-based and time-intensive (teamwork simulations).
Combined with a language-intensive FREN 1226 and writing-heavy HIST 1190, this is a challenging schedule.



4. üßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Wellness Tip
You don‚Äôt have any days fully free ‚Äî consider if you want one lighter day (maybe drop one class or spread across the week differently).

title: Fall 2025 Schedule course registration advice
text:
üßæ Suggestions

‚úÖ If you‚Äôre confident in your time management, this schedule works ‚Äî you‚Äôre touching all bases: quant, writing, discussion, and teamwork.
üõ† Trim or shift one class if you want better pacing ‚Äî perhaps drop HIST 1190 (if not needed for requirements), or ask if LING 0700 recitation is optional.
üß© Be ready for group projects in MGMT and potentially FREN ‚Äî those can stack up in the second half of semester.


Want help checking requirements, alternate sections, or evaluating profs? Happy to dig deeper!

title: Fall 2025 Schedule course registration advice
text:
Thoughts:
Unfortunately, I feel like GPT was not able to offer any additional insights to what I had

title: Travel reccomendations
text: When figuring out where to go for Spring Break, my friends and I had been staring at a map of the US and Europe trying to figure out where to go together. We had reached a point where we really weren‚Äôt sure what we were looking for, so we used AI to narrow down our options. Below, I attached the prompt along with the response we received.

title: Travel reccomendations
text:
Prompt:
Please give me beach vacation destinations 6 hours max from NYC, What about things like Charleston?

title: Travel reccomendations
text:
Response:
Yes! Charleston, South Carolina is a great option, and there are a few similar beach destinations within a 6-hour flight or drive from NYC that offer a mix of historic charm, coastal beauty, and Southern hospitality. Here are some great alternatives:

Southern Beach Destinations (Under 6-Hour Flight)

Charleston, SC (2 hrs by flight) ‚Äì Historic cobblestone streets, waterfront charm, and nearby Folly Beach, Isle of Palms, and Sullivan‚Äôs Island.

Savannah, GA (2.5 hrs by flight) ‚Äì Similar to Charleston, with historic squares and nearby Tybee Island for a laid-back beach escape.

Hilton Head Island, SC (2.5 hrs by flight) ‚Äì A mix of luxury resorts, golf courses, and beautiful beaches.

Wilmington, NC (1.5 hrs by flight) ‚Äì Historic riverfront city with beaches like Wrightsville Beach and Carolina Beach.

Myrtle Beach, SC (2 hrs by flight) ‚Äì More touristy, but great for a mix of golf, beaches, and boardwalk fun.

Virginia Beach, VA (1.5 hrs by flight or 6 hrs drive) ‚Äì A lively boardwalk scene with miles of sandy shoreline.

If you‚Äôre looking for that Charleston-style charm with a beach nearby, I‚Äôd say Charleston, Savannah, or Hilton Head would be your best picks! Let me know if you need help narrowing it down.

title: Travel reccomendations
text:
Reflection:
What was super interesting to me in this interaction was that GPT was able to also extract the flight time from NYC to all of these different destinations. It‚Äôs reccomendations were quite expected, and the description of each destination also included a decent amount of examples of what to do and specific places within each destination. But I‚Äôm curious how it was further able to find the exact flight time from each of these places and find the correct travel time.
Also, I haven‚Äôt directly included the rest of my conversations with GPT but it was quite able to adapt its suggestions and move them to suit what I was asking for, especially when I got very nuanced about what features I wanted in my destination and was picky about the region of the US I would be in.
Alas - I did not heed any of GPT‚Äôs advice and did not end up picking any of these destinations as the final decision.

title: Using GPT for French
text: This scenario of using GPT came to me on a whim and in the moment. This came from a real life application - last Sunday I was working with a Freshman in French 0200 Beginner‚Äôs French and trying to explain these grammar concepts when I decided to try out using Chat GPT. I thought that while there were a lot of straight facts and points that GPT was correct about, it kind of lacked nuance and did not provide information in a way that was easily absorbed by the student, and was instead kind of confusing in the way it seemed to be just regurgitating information in not the most effective way.

title: Using GPT for French
section: 1. Using ChatGPT for Quick Grammar Explanations
text:
1. Using ChatGPT for Quick Grammar Explanations
One of the biggest challenges in learning French is mastering prepositions, articles, and small grammatical details that affect meaning. Recently, I asked ChatGPT to explain the differences between de, dela, and des, and the response gave me a clear, structured breakdown:

De ‚Üí ‚Äúof‚Äù or ‚Äúfrom‚Äù (possession, origin, general use)

Ex: Le livre de Marie. (Marie‚Äôs book.)

Ex: Je viens de Paris. (I come from Paris.)

Dela ‚Üí Rarely used today but historically meant ‚Äúbeyond‚Äù (de l√†). Now written separately.

Ex: Regarde de l√†! (Look from there!)

Des ‚Üí ‚Äúof the‚Äù or ‚Äúsome‚Äù (plural of du/de la or contraction of de + les)

Ex: Les livres des √©tudiants. (The students‚Äô books.)

Ex: Je mange des pommes. (I eat some apples.)



How This Helps When Studying or Tutoring

When teaching, you can ask ChatGPT to explain a concept in simple terms, like I did.

If a student is confused, use AI to generate multiple examples for clarity.

If you‚Äôre self-studying, this method saves time compared to searching in textbooks.

title: Using GPT for French
section: 2. Condensing Complex Topics into Cheat Sheets
text:
2. Condensing Complex Topics into Cheat Sheets
When I asked ChatGPT to condense the explanation into a notecard-sized cheat sheet, it quickly summarized the essential points. This is a great way to:
- Create quick reference guides for key grammar rules.
- Simplify notes for tutoring sessions.
- Help students focus on what‚Äôs most important instead of getting lost in details.
üí° Tip: If you‚Äôre tutoring, ask ChatGPT to simplify explanations based on your student‚Äôs level (beginner, intermediate, advanced).

title: Using GPT for French
section: 3. Applying This to Broader French Learning
text:
3. Applying This to Broader French Learning
Beyond this one example, you can use ChatGPT to improve both personal learning and tutoring sessions in multiple ways:

Grammar & Vocabulary Help

Ask for differences between confusing words (‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the difference between savoir and conna√Ætre?‚Äù).

Get example sentences to show words in context.



Pronunciation Practice

Ask for phonetic transcriptions (‚ÄúHow do I pronounce ‚Äò≈ìuvre‚Äô?‚Äù).

Get tips on common pronunciation mistakes in French.



Practice Exercises & Tutoring Materials

Generate fill-in-the-blank exercises: ‚ÄúProvide a practice quiz for de, du, des.‚Äù

Get short reading passages with comprehension questions.

Simulate real-life conversations (‚ÄúPretend I‚Äôm at a French bakery ordering a croissant.‚Äù).

Using ChatGPT to learn French is like having an on-demand tutor‚Äîit‚Äôs fast, clear, and customizable. Whether you‚Äôre tackling tricky grammar like de, dela, des or creating teaching materials, this AI tool can make studying more efficient and interactive.

title: Using GPT for French
text:
Reflection:
Above, I used GPT with the memory of me prompting it to help me teach a student in French with some prepositions to have it reflect on using GPT to learn languages. I think it did quite a good job of resonating with me and picking the right ideas, since I found that GPT was really good at providing basic information, but then would lack nuance when I asked for more examples. As such, I think that GPT as a tutor is only really useful for simple and beginner level topics, and gets less helpful as you become more advanced with a language.

title: Using GPT for French
text:
Potential final project idea:
Thinking about this blog post, I was talking to my groupmates Sose and Carlos and we were interested in seeing if using more training and priming we would be able to make a LLM specifically prepared for language tutoring, so I think this might be a tentative idea for our final project.

title: Chat GPT for Excel
text: This weekend, I decided to sit down and take a closer look at my personal spending over the months of January and February. This ended up being a task really relevant to data analysis, since I had exported my bank statements of the past month and was trying to organize them in Excel. To figure out how to do this task most efficiently, I ended up asking GPT how to use certain Excel functions, and this made my life easier as it extracted the numbers of each charge from within the large block of text the statements had copied into my spreadsheet as.

title: Chat GPT for Excel
text: This weekend, I decided to sit down and take a closer look at my personal spending over the months of January and February. This ended up being a task really relevant to data analysis, since I had exported my bank statements of the past month and was trying to organize them in Excel. To figure out how to do this task most efficiently, I ended up asking GPT how to use certain Excel functions, and this made my life easier as it extracted the numbers of each charge from within the large block of text the statements had copied into my spreadsheet as.

title: Chat GPT for Excel
text:
GPT Response:
Organizing data in Excel and pulling out numbers effectively depends on what you‚Äôre trying to do. Here are a few techniques:

1. Organizing Data in Excel

Sorting & Filtering

Sort: Go to Data ‚Üí Sort to arrange numbers in ascending or descending order.
Filter: Use Data ‚Üí Filter to show only specific values or conditions.



Using Tables for Better Organization

Select your data and press Ctrl + T to create a structured table.
This makes filtering, sorting, and referencing easier.



Removing Duplicates

Go to Data ‚Üí Remove Duplicates to clean your dataset.





2. Pulling Out Numbers from Text (Extracting Numeric Values)

Using Excel Functions
If your data contains numbers mixed with text, use: - Extract numbers only: excel   =TEXTJOIN("", TRUE, IF(ISNUMBER(MID(A1, ROW(INDIRECT("1:" & LEN(A1))), 1) * 1), MID(A1, ROW(INDIRECT("1:" & LEN(A1))), 1), "")) - Press Ctrl + Shift + Enter (Array formula for older versions). - In Excel 365, press Enter directly.

Extract first number (if it‚Äôs always at the end):
=LOOKUP(9^9, --MID(A1, ROW($1:$100), 1))



Using Flash Fill (Easy Method)

If your data is in Column A, type the extracted number manually in Column B.
Press Ctrl + E after entering a few examples, and Excel will automatically extract numbers.





3. Pulling Specific Data with Formulas

VLOOKUP:
=VLOOKUP(lookup_value, table_array, column_index, FALSE)
(Use when data is structured in columns.)
INDEX-MATCH (Better than VLOOKUP):
=INDEX(B:B, MATCH(lookup_value, A:A, 0))
(Finds a value in Column B that corresponds to a match in Column A.)
FILTER Function (Excel 365/2021):
=FILTER(A:A, ISNUMBER(A:A))
(Pulls out only numbers from a column.)

Would you like help with a specific case? üöÄ

title: Chat GPT for Excel
text:
Follow up about copy pasting:
To copy and paste just the number values in Excel without the formula, follow these steps:

Method 1: Paste Special (Values Only)

Select the cells with the numbers you want to copy.
Press Ctrl + C (or Cmd + C on Mac) to copy.
Right-click the destination cell and choose Paste Special > Values (or press Ctrl + Alt + V, then press V, and hit Enter).



Method 2: Using Keyboard Shortcuts

Select the cells with formulas.
Press Ctrl + C to copy.
Move to the destination cell.
Press Ctrl + Shift + V (on newer versions of Excel) OR
Press Alt + E, S, V (older versions) and then hit Enter.



Method 3: Using ‚ÄúValues‚Äù Option from Ribbon

Select the data.
Click Home ‚Üí Paste dropdown (‚ñº).
Click Paste Values (123 icon).

This will paste only the numeric values, removing all formulas. Let me know if you need more help! üòä

title: Chat GPT for Excel
text:
Reflection:
This was a bit of a shift from some of my previous reflections and blog posts, where I tried to use GPT for something a little more applied or academic. However, here, I found that GPT was actually worse off when it was given a really general goal, and instead was bad at being able to parse out what information was important. This is why it became difficult to understand its output because it gave me many different equations and formulas that would be helpful, but could not explain which use cases they would be used for.
In the end, through trial and error I believe I was able to make it work. Also, with the table function and sorting I was able to discover that I probably eat too much Just Salad.
